CompColl.description:
How this coverage works

Comprehensive coverage pays for a vehicle that's stolen or damaged by causes other than collision or upset. Some examples include damage caused by: fire, wind, hail, earthquake, theft, vandalism, or hitting animals in the road. It will also pay for substitute transportation expenses up to $25 a day ($750 maximum) if your car is stolen. Payments will be made beginning when you tell us of the theft.

Collision coverage pays for a covered vehicle that is damaged by collision with another object or by the overturning of the vehicle.

A deductible is required for these coverages and represents the amount you pay before insurance covers any remaining costs. Please note that if you lease or have a lien on your covered vehicle, your lessor or lienholder may require you to buy these coverages.

If no glass deductible is offered in your state then it applies only to Comprehensive coverage. Please review the policy contract for coverage details in your state.

How high should my deductible be?

Higher deductibles lower your premium, but increase the amount you'll have to pay out of your own pocket for accidental damage to your car. Ask yourself how much risk you're willing to take to save money on premiums and calculate the maximum amount you can pay out of pocket.

Coverage in action

Let's say a tree falls on Blake's car during a thunderstorm. His car has major damage, but thankfully, he's not injured.

It's not Blake's fault, but these things happen. The damage to his car will cost $1,500 to repair and his deductible is $500. Blake's Comprehensive coverage covers the remaining $1,000 for the repairs.

or

It's just not Aaron's day. On the way to work, his car went off the road striking a tree. His car has major damage, but fortunately, he wasn't injured.

The damage to his car will cost $4000 to repair and his deductible is $500. Aaron's Collision coverage covers the remaining $3,500 for the repairs.

Liability.formalName: Bodily Injury and Property Damage Liability Coverage
Liability.description:
How this coverage works

Bodily Injury and Property Damage Liability coverages pay for damages to others if you are legally responsible. If you are sued, it also pays for your defense and court costs.

Medical expenses, pain and suffering, and lost wages are some examples of bodily injury damages. Property damage includes damage to property and its loss of use.

How high should my limits be?

Nobody can tell you the most you will have to pay if you cause an auto accident. Consider your ability to pay any damages that exceed your policy limits with your own money. The higher your limits are, the more protection we will be able to provide for you.

Coverage in action

Let's say Steve's car collides with a stopped car at an intersection. The driver and passenger in the car he hit are injured, and their luxury car is totaled.

If Steve is legally responsibleâ€”or liableâ€”for the accident, Bodily Injury Liability coverage may pay for medical expenses up to his limits per person and per accident. If Steve's Property Damage limit is $50,000, he may be responsible for paying the balance on their $70,000 car. If the other driver sues him, it pays for his defense and court costs.
Liability.shortDescription: Pays for injuries to other people and damage to their property when you are at fault.

MEDPM.description:
How this coverage works

Medical Payments coverage pays up to the limit you select per person for medical and funeral expenses, for bodily injury sustained by a covered person in an auto accident. The bodily injury must be initially treated within one year after the accident. The medical expenses must be reasonable and necessary, and the medical expenses must be provided within one year immediately following the date of the accident.

The most we will pay for funeral expenses is the lower of your limit or $3000.

How high should my limits be?

Nobody can tell you the most you will have to pay if you are injured in an auto accident. Consider your personal health insurance coverage and your ability to pay for medical treatment. The higher your limits are, the more protection we will be able to provide for you.

Coverage in action

While Sabrina is driving in a snowstorm, she slides off the road and hits a tree. The impact injures her and an ambulance takes her to the hospital for treatment.

Sabrina's emergency medical treatment costs $2,500, but her health insurance deductible requires her to pay $1,500 out of pocket. Sabrina's Medical Payments coverage will help her pay her deductible and any other reasonable medical expenses related to her accident injuries that are not covered by her health insurance.
MEDPM.shortDescription: Helps pay for medical expenses if you or your passengers are injured in an accident.

RAC.selectorLabel: Would you like to add this coverage?
RAC.description:
How this coverage works

Emergency Road Service coverage pays the fair cost for the following emergency services for a covered vehicle:

â€¢ Mechanical labor for up to one hour at the place of breakdown.
â€¢ Towing to the nearest place where repairs can be made.
â€¢ Towing the vehicle out if it is stuck on or next to a public road.
â€¢ Delivery of gas, oil, battery, or change of tire, but not the cost of such items.
â€¢ Locksmith labor for up to one hour to unlock a covered car if its key is lost, stolen, or locked inside the vehicle.

Who do I call when I need help?

You may call HiRoad's Emergency Road Service or any service provider in the area. This coverage lets you choose who comes to your aid.

Coverage in action

Eric's car breaks down on the side of the road in an unfamiliar area, leaving him stranded on the side of the road. Unsure who to call, Eric contacts HiRoad Emergency Road Service through the HiRoad app and they dispatch assistance to his location.

His Roadside Assistance coverage pays for his towing or minor mechanical repair so he can get back on the road.
RAC.shortDescription: Helps pay for the cost of emergency services.

RREIM.formalName: Car Rental and Travel Expenses Coverage
RREIM.selectorLabel: Would you like to add this coverage?
RREIM.description:
How this coverage works

Car Rental and Travel Expenses coverage pays up to $40 per day ($1,200 max per occurrence) for you to rent a car or pay for alternative sources of transportation such as a TNCs like Uber or Lyft, train, taxi or bus. You can be reimbursed up to the daily limit when your car is not drivable due to a loss that would be payable under Comprehensive or Collision Coverage.

It also pays up to $500 total for the following incurred expenses for all persons when your car is not drivable as a result of a loss that occurs more than 50 miles from home, including: meals, lodging, and transportation home or on to your destination, and the return trip to pick up your car.

Coverage in action

Jason's car is in the shop after a collision, leaving him without a way to get to work or run errands until the repairs are complete.

Rental reimbursement pays for car rental expense while his car is being repaired and Jason is relieved to have less interruption to his routine.

or

Rental reimbursement covers Jason's Uber rides while his car is being repaired. This helps keep his normal schedule as much as possible.
RREIM.shortDescription: Helps pay car rental and travel expenses when your vehicle is damaged.

UIMBI.description:
How these coverages work

Uninsured or Underinsured Motorist Bodily Injury coverages pay for damages when you are involved in a car accident caused by another person who does not have enough or any liability insurance. Medical expenses and lost wages are some examples of bodily injury damages.

Coverage in action

An uninsured driver runs a red light and hits the side of Karen's car. She and her passenger end up in the hospital for several days.

Because she was injured by someone driving without any liability, Karen's Uninsured Motorist Bodily Injury coverage helps pay for her medical expenses. Additionally, Karen and her passenger's lost wages or pain and suffering may be covered.

or

An underinsured driver is distracted and rear ends Aaronâ€™s car at a stop sign. He is injured and requires treatment for several months to recover fully.

Because he was injured by someone driving with insufficient liability limits, Aaron's Underinsured Motorist Bodily Injury coverage helps pay for any of his additional medical expenses that are not covered by the at-fault driverâ€™s insurance. Additionally, Aaron's lost wages or pain and suffering may be covered.

* RI, NV customers: Underinsured Motorist - Bodily Injury coverage is included as part of Uninsured Motorist - Bodily Injury coverage.
Note: Please review the policy contract for coverage details in your state.

Additionally, Aaron's lost wages or pain and suffering may be covered.

* RI, NV customers: Underinsured Motorist - Bodily Injury coverage is included as part of Uninsured Motorist - Bodily Injury coverage.
Note: Please review the policy contract for coverage details in your state.
UMBI.shortDescription: Helps pay for injuries to you when the other driver is at fault and doesn't have sufficient insurance.

DLossOfUse.description: If you canâ€™t live in your place after a loss, this pays for lodging and living expenses until you can move back in.
DLossOfUse.shortDescription: If you canâ€™t live in your place after a loss, this pays for lodging and living expenses until you can move back in.

EPersonalLiability.description:
If there's an accident in your home, you could be held legally responsible.

This coverage pays for your legal liability (subject to policy limits) for injuries or property damage caused by an applicable event. In addition, it may provide for the payment of your defense against these claims or suits.

If you break or damage someone else's property, your policy can help pay to replace it.

Scenario: it's been a tough week at work, and looking to unwind you begin filling the bath to settle in and relax. Right then Elle texts you to see if you want to grab a beer, so you head out. You get home to find a furious downstairs neighbor â€” you forgot to turn off the water, and now your neighbor's belongings are waterlogged and ruined.

Scenario: today your rescue pup, Maverick, was chasing a ball in the park when a young boy got excited and tried to take it from him to throw it again. Before you knew it, Maverick grabbed the ball from the boy and accidentally nipped his fingers. There's not even a scratch, but the boy's parents are threatening to sue you!

In these situations, Personal Liability can help pay for the damages you're legally responsible for, or help defend you against any legal action.
EPersonalLiability.shortDescription:
If your guest gets hurt at your place, or your dog bites someone and you get sued,
this is what pays legal and medical costs.

Earthquake.description: Protect your stuff during that shake, rattle and roll. Heads up, a deductible applies to this coverage.
Earthquake.shortDescription: Protect your stuff during that shake, rattle and roll. Heads up, a deductible applies to this coverage.

FMedicalPayments.description: If someone gets hurt on my property, this helps pay their medical bills.
FMedicalPayments.shortDescription: If someone gets hurt on my property, this helps pay their medical bills.

IdentityTheft.formalName: Cyber Event, Identity Restoration, and Fraud Loss
IdentityTheft.description: Protect the real you (and your credit!) when someone else pretends to be you.
IdentityTheft.shortDescription: Protect the real you (and your credit!) when someone else pretends to be you.

JF.description:
Covers loss by theft of jewelry, watches, precious and semi-precious stones, and fur or fur-trimmed garments. The default renters policy limits theft coverage for these items to $1,000; with this optional coverage, you can purchase higher limits of $2,500, $5,000, or $10,000. Increasing your coverage to a higher limit will also provide coverage for accidental physical loss.

While honeymooning on Maui, Ryan and Hayley are enjoying surfing lessons. Hayley's enjoyment turns to panic when she realizes her new wedding ring is no longer on her finger. Adding Jewelry and Furs optional coverage adds protection for accidental losses like this.
JF.shortDescription: When you have cha-ching invested in your bling, protect it.

PersonalPropertyDeductible.description: What you pay upfront before insurance kicks in.
PersonalPropertyDeductible.shortDescription: What you pay upfront before insurance kicks in.

PersonalPropertyLimit.description:
Coverage for your personal belongings. Personal property coverage protects your belongings anywhere in the world.

Scenario 1: you're embracing mindful living, and have taken up biking to work. You're feeling good about your increased fitness and decreased carbon footprint, until you come out of work on Monday to findyour bike's been stolen.

Scenario 2: you've waited a long time for the weekend trip to New York with your friends. But while you're away, your apartment is broken into and your laptop, sunglasses, and leather jacket are gone!

In both of these situations, Personal Property coverage will help you pay to replace these items (subject to your deductible and policy limits).
PersonalPropertyLimit.shortDescription: Pays for your stuff no matter where it is when stolen or damaged.

WaterBackupOfSewerAndDrain.description:
Provides coverage for damage caused by water which backs up through sewers or drains, including sump pumps, sump pump wells, or any type of system designed to remove surface water. (Coverage is subject to limits selected; will be an additional amount on your bill.)

A backed-up sewer can make a real mess in your home, causing damage to your things that are exposed to the water and sewage backup. This coverage can help you repair or replace damaged items.
WaterBackupOfSewerAndDrain.shortDescription: Protect your stuff and your space when what should stay down comes up.
